trait.name: Explosive Scales
entries: The bazelgeuse's scales, when dislodged from its body, act as a time bomb. On initiative count 20 (losing all initiative ties) all scales explode dealing 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage to all creature in a 5-foot radius of them.

trait.name: Shed
entries: Whenever the bazelguese makes a melee weapon attack, it dislodges an explosive scale which lands in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of its location.

trait.name: Carpet Bomb
entries: For every 20 feet the bazelgeuse flies, it dislodges an explosive scale which lands in an unoccupied space directly below it.

trait.name: Wounded Fury
entries: While it has 56 hit points or fewer, the bazelgeuse enters a "super-heated" state, gaining advantage on attack rolls. In addition, Explosive Scales detonate at the end of the bazelgeuse's turn.

trait.name: Dive Attack
entries: If the bazelgeuse is flying and dives at least 30 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a headbutt attack, the attack deals an extra 4 ({@damage 1d8}) damage to the target.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bazelgeuse makes three attacks; one headbutt attack, one tail attack, and one wing attack.

action.name: Headbutt
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit 19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Wing
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit 22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit 16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The bazelgeuse exhales fire in a 45-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 46 ({@damage 7d12}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

{@i Hurtling through the dense jungle, a large tyrannosaur crashes to the forest floor. Scrambling to its feet, the jagged scaled embedded in its hide begin to flash red as a winged predator leaps towards the startled dinosaur. As the creature’s talons make contact with the tyrannosaur’s flesh, the scales erupt, enveloping both animals in a violent explosion.}

{@b Armored Flesh.} Soaring above plateaus, grasslands, and wherever else they may find prey, the bazelgeuse is a large, wyvern-like beast covered in thick, bumpy scales with a bronze sheen. These scales are backed by a protective layer of identical scales, forming an impenetrable shield of keratin.

{@b B-72 Bomber.} The bazelgeuse's most distinctive feature is its ability to shed its scales, which act like timed bombs. These explosive scales are composed by the solidification of carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen, forming a dense, destructive fragment of keratin. Once dislodged, these scales detonate after a time, in a manner similar to a mine. However, when the beast enters its "super-heated" state, the scales detonate almost immediately. A bazalgeuse will use its enormous body to overwhelm foes and the combustive power of its scales to scorch them when battling up-close. They prefer to fight in the air. shedding their explosive scales over a wide area in a manner so they can prey on whatever gets caught in the blast, like destructive vultures.

{@b Thrilled Combatant.} Nomadic hunters, bazelgeuse easily assert themselves as apex predators in whatever environment they pass through, disrupting the local food chain. They will violently brawl other large predators without hesitation, even diving into fights that don’t seem to involve them in the slightest. With an insatiable lust for combat, these beasts will attack other creatures regardless of their size but seem to gravitate towards other apex species, such as dragons, wyverns, and large dinosaurs.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The brachydios makes three attacks, one with its horn and two with its fists.

action.name: Horn
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit 20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire and bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit 17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire and bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Chemical Reaction {@recharge 5}
entries: The brachydios slams its horn into the ground and causes a chain of explosions in a 60 foot line that is 10 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) fire damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. On a failed or successful save, the target is knocked {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The brachydios moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Pound
entries: The brachydios makes a fist attack.

legendary.name: Slam (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The brachydios makes a horn attack or uses chemical reaction.

{@i A massive theropod stomps through the cavernous tunnel, volatile, green goo dripping from two blunt, murderous forelimbs hanging from its shoulders. As this mucus hits the ground, it sizzles and burns with a long, smoky hiss.}

Brachydios are easily identifiable by their glowing, green slime-covered horns and "fists," as well as their shiny, armored hide covered in many chitinous plates and ridges that are made of obsidian. Unlike most other beasts, the brachydios sports a pair of long, highly developed forelimbs that it uses as its primary means of defense. Their “fists” and horns secrete a volatile, incendiary slime.

A Brachydios "primes" this mucus to explode with its saliva, causing it to lick its arms compulsively before attacking. When primed, the slime glows a bright green and emits harsh levels of heat. Despite initial appearances, the brachydios does possess claws on its forearms that are tucked away underneath, and are used to forage and grasp.

The symbiotic slime-mold is easily one of the most unique and defining features of the brachydios. The theropod's armored shell is hardened to protect against the explosive blasts that the mold creates on impact. A brachydios' skin is similar to that of a thermos flask, giving it the ability to withstand both extreme heat and cold. A brachydios' body is the only place this mold can survive without becoming explosive. When attacking, a brachydios will obsessively scrape copious amounts of this mold off of its body, causing it to deplete. However, it seems that the beast's saliva acts as a powerful stimulant, which causes the mold to almost instantly replenish itself.

Brachydios are extremely aggressive creatures and will not hesitate to attack if they feel threatened or challenged. Due to their aggression they are commonly known to invade the territories of other large predators, usurp them, and claim the territory as their own. Additionally, they will show absolutely no mercy to smaller, weaker creatures. Young will live near their parents and their territory, yet the adults will not show any parental care at all. The young will pick up slime mold left behind by adults, attaching it to their carapace. However, this can prove  to be dangerous as their hides are underdeveloped and can accidentally trigger an explosion, causing the young brachydios to be seriously injured or even killed by the explosion produced.

trait.name: Rampage
entries: When the odogaron reduces a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on its turn, the odogaron can take a bonus action to move up to half its speed and make a claw attack.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the odogaron moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the odogaron can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The odogaron makes three attacks; one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}).

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit 11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or lose 5 ({@dice 1d6}) hit points at the start of each of its turns due to an bloody wound. Each time the odogaron hits the wounded target with this attack, the damage dealt by the wound increases by 5 ({@dice 1d6}). Any creature can take an action to stanch the wound with a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom (Medicine) check. The wound also closes if the target receives magical healing.

reaction.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: The odogaron halves the damage that it takes from an attack that hits it. The odogaron must be able to see the attacker.

{@i Slinking along the caverns of the underdark, a monster resembling a cross between a tiger, a hyena, and a crocodile stalks the darkness. Two rows of serrated, hook-like claws cling to the wet stone, allowing it to pounce and tear with gruesome efficiency.}

{@b Chimeric Scavenger.}The odogaron is a dangerous underdark predator who prefers to scavenge on carrion rather than prey on other organisms. It is covered in deep red scales and bony protrusions that resemble muscle tissue and bone, most notably its tail, which it occasionally uses as a club. Odogaron have potent blue eyes, perfect for stalking unsuspecting prey and effortlessly piercing through the darkness of its preferred habitat. An odogaron’s most distinctive feature is its double row of claws, which it uses to inflict deep, grievous gashes into its prey, causing them to rapidly bleed to death.

{@b Opportunistic Predators.} Despite its size, the odogaron is quite an agile animal. It will often rush any chosen prey before delivering a flurry of rending bites with its powerful, bone-crushing jaws, tearing flesh from nutritious, rich bone. Residing underneath the surface, the odogaron consumes what it can find, filling a similar niche to a vulture. However, it will occasionally venture to the surface in search of prey, where it assumes an apex role in the food chain alongside the likes of organisms such as Legiana.

{@b Confident Carnivores.} The odogaron is a commonly docile creature, though wary of most large creatures, similar to most apex predators. If provoked, an odogaron will fight to the death, no matter how dangerous or intimidating the encountered force is. Brasher individuals are even willing to attack adult dragons despite essentially confronting a primordial force. As a result of its neutral nature, some sentient underdark civilizations have managed to tame a few members of the species, utilizing them as swift, deadly mounts.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The kravgaera has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The kravgaera can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The kravgaera can burrow through solid rock at half its burrow speed and leaves a 10-foot-diameter tunnel in its wake.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The kravgaera doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kravgaera attacks once with its bite and twice with its claws. Alternatively, it makes two sonic lance attacks or two explosion attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained} and the kravgaera can't bite another target or use any attack that deals thunder damage. When the kravgaera moves, any target it is grappling moves with it.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Sonic Lance
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +11} to hit, range 40/120 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 8d8}) thunder damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} and {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Explosion
entries: The kravgaera fires its sonic lance at a point on the ground, a large rock, stone wall, or similar terrain within 60 feet, causing the terrain to explode. Creatures within a 15-foot-radius sphere around the target point must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing and thunder damage on a failed save and be knocked {@condition prone} or half as much damage and remain standing on a successful one.

action.name: Deafening Screech {@recharge 5}
entries: The kravgaera roars loudly in a 15-foot-radius around it. Structures and unattended objects in the area take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) thunder damage. All creatures in the area become {@condition deafened} and must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 49 ({@damage 7d10}) thunder damage on a failed saving throw or half as much on a successful one.

{@italic This feathered, colorful pterosaur is covered by several rows of serrated spikes and jagged scales. The air near its toothed beak, large enough to carry a horse, visibly vibrates with sound pulses.}
High in the skies of Chult, kravgaera scream other aireborne creatures out of the sky, grabbing them nimbly out of the air before plunging deep into the earth to consume their prey.

{@bold Scourge of the Skies.} Above the prehistoric jungles of chult, the kravgaera thrive and dominate, controlling the skies with a tyrannical scream. The ear-piercing shriek of these apex predators is enough to clear out entire populations of birds and pterosaurs, allowing them to scatter prey easily and claim territory with little to no competition. These bold predators will even battle large terrestrial animals for territory and are even known to prey on the occasional elephant or hadrosaur. These predators are covered in a thick, serrated carapace that allows them to burrow by writhing and “swimming” through the earth. They utilize their burrowing ability by transitioning to earth and sky rapidly, disorienting prey. These emperors of the sky even manage to hold their own against dragons, although they can’t survive a prolonged battle. As a result, these normally solitary and territorial creatures may band together to bully the magical reptiles out of the sky, thus condemning most dragons to the ground.

{@bold Blind Fliers.} Most sentient creatures think bats to be completely blind, navigating through keen senses and subsonic vibrations. Whilst this is simply misinformation, the kravgaera are truly blind, locating prey through echolocation and navigating via an internal GPS system, which is yet to be truly understood. It is theorized that, due to the creature’s vulnerability to electromagnesis, the kravgaera have an innate organ covered in specialized photoreceptors that allows the reptile to sense the planet’s Geomagnetism, similar to birds. However, this has yet to be proven, as the jungles of Chult rarely preserve the bodies of the dead, which are either scavenged or reanimated. Watching the rotting corpse of a zombified kravgaera soar through the tropical sky is an eerie sight, and it’s of the watcher’s best interest to hide before they are spotted.

{@bold Sonic Screams.} The screams of a kravgaera can be summarized by two words; loud and dangerous. These ear-splitting pterosaurs are capable of shrieking loud enough to emit powerful bursts of sound, acting as a concentrated explosion when colliding with a physical surface. These concentrated blasts are devastating to both organic and inorganic material, capable of causing severe physical damage and even destroying terrain. While deadly to potential prey and would-be predators, these sonic bursts are most devastating to other kravgaera, overloading their senses and causing them to plummet to the ground. It isn’t uncommon to find rival males nimbly evading each other, firing powerful shockwaves at one another before one is sent cascading to the jungle floor below, leaving only one to be the true emperor of the skies.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The alchemical skunk has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The alchemical skunk has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The alchemical skunk uses its Alchemical Spray. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Alchemical Spray
entries: The alchemical skunk raises its tail and sprays an alchemical mixture. The skunk is immune to its own spray effects and to the spray effects of other alchemical skunks. Roll a {@dice d6} to determine the skunk's spray.

items.name: Pleasant Mist.
items.entry: The skunk produces a rosy mist. Each creature within 10 feet of the skunk must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Shrinking Cloud.
items.entry: The skunk releases a yellow gas. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be reduced as if targeted by the {@spell enlarge/reduce} spell for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: Laughing Gas.
items.entry: The skunk emits a sparkling orange cloud. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition incapacitated} as it laughs for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: Blinding Spray.
items.entry: The skunk shoots a stream of a green fluid. Each creature in a line that is 30 feet long and 5 feet wide must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute, or until the creature uses an action to wipe its eyes.

items.name: Sleeping Fog.
items.entry: The skunk sprays a sweet-smelling blue fog. Each creature within 10 feet of the skunk must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. The creature wakes up if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

items.name: Poison Fog.
items.entry: The skunk excretes a foul-smelling purple fog around itself until the start of its next turn. Each creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the skunk must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn.

entries: The large skunk waddles forward, sniffing at a spilled potion. As a sound nearby startles it, the skunk raises its tail, and the stripes on its back change color.

entries.name: Magical Prank
entries: The unfortunate result of a magic school prank, alchemical skunks were created when an ordinary skunk was forced to drink a combination of potions. Despite their larger size, alchemical skunks still look and act like ordinary skunks, except for the ever-changing color of the stripes on their backs. Experienced foresters know that the colors on the alchemical skunk's back indicate which magical malady the creature is about to spray and do their best to avoid aggravating these dangerous creatures.

entries.name: Laboratory Pests
entries: Alchemical skunks forage the same as their nonmagical kin, but they are also regularly found scavenging the waste of alchemical laboratories. They enjoy feasting on potions and potion components, much to the dismay of alchemists and adventurers alike.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The anzu has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The anzu makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its talons.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Breath Weapons {@recharge 5}
entries: The anzu uses one of the following breath weapons:

items.name: Fire Breath.
items.entry: The anzu exhales fire in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Water Breath.
items.entry: The anzu exhales a wave of water in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 38 ({@damage 11d6}) bludgeoning damage and is pushed up to 30 feet away from the anzu and knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Lightning Relocation
entries: The anzu teleports up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space it can see. When it does, it briefly transforms into a bolt of lightning, flashes upwards, then crashes down unharmed at its destination. Each creature within 5 feet of the anzu's starting location or destination must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. A creature within 5 feet of both locations makes this saving throw only once.
A giant macaw roars out its fury in spouts of fire and scalding water while lightning crackles through its feathers.

entries.name: Territorial
entries: Anzu are fierce and territorial predators, claiming ranges along the edges of deserts, wide grasslands, or high mountains. Extremely long-lived, they mate for life, producing two or three eggs every decade.

entries.name: Elemental Birthright
entries: Offspring of a wind god or primordial wind spirit, anzu are the personification of the south wind, lightning, and the driving monsoon. Uniquely tied to the elements of fire, water, and wind, they react poorly to weather altering magic.

trait.name: Bony Body
entries: A creature that starts its turn or enters the space within 5 feet of the bonespitter must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bonespitter makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its bone spike.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the bonespitter. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the bonespitter, and it takes 17 ({@damage 5d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the bonespitter's turns. An undead creature made of mostly bones, such as a {@creature skeleton}, is immune to this acid damage.

If the bonespitter takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the bonespitter must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the bonespitter. If the bonespitter dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Bone Spike
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +13} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is knocked {@condition prone}, pinned to the ground by the spike, and {@condition restrained}. As an action, the {@condition restrained} creature or a creature within 5 feet of it can make a {@dc 18} Strength check, removing the spike and ending the condition on a success. The spike can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 12; hp 15; vulnerability to bludgeoning damage; immunity to poison and psychic damage).

action.name: Shard Spray {@recharge 5}
entries: The bonespitter exhales a 60-foot cone of bone shards. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 35 ({@damage 10d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. If a Large or smaller creature fails this saving throw, it is also knocked {@condition prone}, pinned to the ground by a shard, and {@condition restrained}. As an action, the {@condition restrained} creature or a creature within 5 feet of it can make a {@dc 18} Strength check, removing the shard and ending the condition on a success. The shard can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 12; hp 15; vulnerability to bludgeoning damage; immunity to poison and psychic damage).
A massive worm bursts through the ground, its body covered in bony protrusions.
Bonespitters are bone-covered predators that live in the soft soil of grassy plains.

entries.name: Bones of Victims
entries: Bonespitters have unique digestive systems. When a bonespitter consumes another creature, the acid in the worm's stomach dissolves all of the prey's tissue and leaves only bones behind. The bones become part of the bonespitter's defenses, poking through its skin like sharp hair follicles. Other bones are stored in muscular sacks in the bonespitter's mouth, waiting to be unleashed on unsuspecting prey.

monster.name: Colláis
languages: understands Common and Sylvan but can't speak

trait.name: Impale and Toss
entries: When the colláis hits a Medium or smaller creature with a gore attack, it can use a bonus action to impale and toss the creature. The target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) piercing damage and be flung up to 10 feet away from the colláis in a random direction and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The colláis has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The colláis makes one gore attack and two hooves attacks.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cry of the Forest
entries: The colláis sounds a dreadful and reverberating call. Each creature within 100 feet of the colláis that can hear the cry must succeed on a {@dc 16} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the colláis's Cry of the Forest for the next 24 hours. Forest-dwelling beasts and monstrosities with an Intelligence of 4 or lower automatically succeed or fail on this saving throw, the colláis's choice.

The colláis is a large, deer-like creature covered in thick, black fur. A great rack of antlers grows from its thick skull, in which prominent eye sockets display two red embers for eyes. The creature has no mouth; instead, a coarse beard grows in its place.

entries.name: Summoned Protector
entries: If a forest village is in danger, the villagers might perform a ritual sacrifice to summon a colláis. Once the ritual is complete, the creature appears in the branches of a nearby tree. It then stalks the village and its surroundings. A colláis returns to  the Feywild after 24 hours.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The cryoceros has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the cryoceros moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its gore attack on the same turn, the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the cryoceros can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The cryoceros can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shards of Ice {@recharge 4}
entries: The cryoceros exhales razor-sharp ice in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage and 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.
This enormous, squat beast has a shaggy hide of ice. Two translucent horns protrude from its snout, the frontmost of which looks like a scimitar.

entries.name: Elemental-Touched Rhino
entries: A cryoceros resembles a woolly rhinoceros made of ice. Its thick, frozen hide protects the soft flesh at its core, and a layer of ice forms over its already formidable, keratinous horns. The creature's body is efficient at transferring warmth to its fleshy interior; fire still harms a cryoceros, but its icy form is not unduly damaged by fiery attacks. A cryoceros has a second stomach that stores ice it consumes. As a defense mechanism, the cryoceros can spew stinging, pulverized ice from this alternate stomach.

entries.name: Slow Metabolisms
entries: Cryoceroses survive on stunted grasses and other plants that thrive in the tundra, as well as ice and snow, to replenish their icy exteriors. Despite their size, they don't require a great deal of sustenance, and they conserve their energy by slowly grazing across frozen plains. Their ponderous movement fools the unwary into believing that distance equals safety. Indeed, cryoceroses endure much provocation before they decide to act, but they run at and spear or crush those who irritate them. Once their ire is up, they rarely give up pursuing the source of their anger; only by leaving their vast territories can one hope to escape them.

entries.name: Cantankerous Mounts
entries: Gentleness and a regular source of food temporarily earns the cryoceroses' trust, and patient humanoids can manage to train the creatures to accept riders. This works for convenience much more than for combat, since cryoceroses balk at fighting with loads on their backs. A cryoceros in combat with a rider either stands stock still until its rider dismounts or, worse, rolls over to throw its rider, often crushing the rider in the process. Because of this, most tribes who train cryoceroses use the creatures as beasts of burden rather than war mounts.

trait.name: Awful Stench
entries: The vulture has a disgusting body odor. Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the vulture must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The vulture has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The vulture has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the vulture's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The death vulture makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Decaying Breath {@recharge 6}
entries: The vulture breathes necrotic energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) necrotic damage on a failed save and be afflicted with {@condition flesh rot}, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The putrid stench of death wafts off a grotesquely muscled vulture with glowing green eyes. It opens its mouth in a shrill call, rotting meat dripping from its beak.
Death vultures are giant birds transformed by their diet of undead flesh.

entries.name: Mutated Monstrosities
entries: When a giant vulture gorges on undead flesh, the necromantic magic suffused in the meal warps and changes the bird's body. The vulture's muscles bulge in odd places, making it stronger and tougher, its eyes burn with green fire, and it reeks of rot, earning these mutated monsters the name "death vultures." The vulture also gains the ability to regurgitate necromantic energy, which can cause the flesh of living creatures to decay and rot rapidly.

entries.name: Massive Meat Appetites
entries: Death vultures have incredible appetites and are far more willing to attack live prey than other vultures. They have a special taste for rotting flesh, and they use their decaying breath weapon to "season" their foes with necrotic energy before using their talons and beaks to tear apart their quarry.

entries.name: Necromancer Neighbors
entries: Death vultures often form kettles near the lairs of necromancers as they feed on their undead creations. While some necromancers find the birds to be a nuisance, many necromancers feed the vultures, encouraging them to stay. Most death vultures are willing to trade service as guardians of the lairs for food.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The huecambra makes three attacks: one with its bite, one with its claw, and one with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or become cursed. While cursed, the creature grows gem-like growths across its body. When the cursed creature takes damage that isn't poison or psychic, it and each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This damage doesn't trigger further explosions. The curse lasts until it is lifted by a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Gem Explosion {@recharge 6}
entries: The huecambra causes some of the gem-like nodules on its body to detonate. Each creature within 20 feet of the huecambra must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 24 ({@damage 7d6}) thunder damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition stunned}. A creature cursed by the huecambra's bite has disadvantage on this saving throw.

The squat lizard's body is dappled gray and chocolate-brown and covered in colorful, wart-like gems, most prominently over its back and along its thick tail. It has long claws, a mouth full of needle-like fangs, and a gleam of intelligence in its multifaceted amber eyes.

entries.name: Mysterious Jungle Hunters
entries: The huecambra is an unusual and rarely seen predator native to tropical jungles and swamps. It hides amid tall reeds or in murky stretches of water, covering itself in mud to hide the gleam of the gem-like growths covering its body. Basilisks, crocodiles, and venomous snakes are the favored prey of a huecambra, though it eats just about anything it can catch. While the true origin of the huecambra remains a mystery, the people of the jungles and swamps where the monster lives believe the creature to be born from the soul of a person overcome with greed and vanity.

entries.name: Gems with Teeth
entries: The huecambra is often hunted for its gem-like growths, which are useful in constructing magic items that protect their wearers from petrification and poison. The luster of the gems also inspires humanoids to hunt them, and brooches and necklaces of huecambra gems are popular items among the social elite of certain countries and city-states.

trait.name: Nauseous Gas
entries: The kezai produces a faint, nauseating gas. Any creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the kezai must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage. The area within 20 feet of the kezai is lightly obscured by the thin gas.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kezai makes three attacks: one with its poison barb and two with its claws.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Poison Barb
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns.

action.name: Searing Acid {@recharge 6}
entries: The kezai's mandibles drip a searing acid, instantly igniting the gas around it. Each creature within 20 feet of the kezai must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The kezai's Nauseous Gas trait becomes inactive for 1 minute. The kezai can't use Searing Gas unless Nauseous Gas has been active for at least 1 minute.
This creature looks much like a human-sized scorpion with wide, laced wings. The tip of its curled tail holds numerous barbs that drip sticky poison.

entries.name: Chemical Killing Machine
entries: The kezai is a creature that lives in hot climates and wages a chemical war on anything that opposes it. It emits a foul poison from its tail, coating the barbs that it hurls at enemies. If this wasn't deadly enough, it naturally produces a thin, flammable gas that it can ignite with a searing chemical produced in a gland near its mandibles. Fortunately for those who come across the kezai, the gland is slow-acting and takes time to produce the chemical necessary to ignite the gas.

trait.name: Corrosive Mold
entries: A creature that starts its turn {@condition grappled} by the kirikari must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or take 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

trait.name: Misty Veil
entries: The kirikari emits a light fog within 30 feet of itself. The mist moves with the kirikari, lightly obscuring the area around it. If dispersed by a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour), the mist reappears at the start of the kirikari's next turn.

trait.name: Unseen Attacker
entries: On each of its turns, the kirikari can use a bonus action to take the {@action Hide} action. If the kirikari is hidden from a creature and hits it with an attack, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage from the attack.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kirikari makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d12 + 5}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the kirikari can't bite another target.

action.name: Blinding Veil {@recharge 5}
entries: The kirikari expels a cloud of intensified mist, heavily obscuring everything within 30 feet of it. The mist thins back to lightly obscuring the area at the end of the kirikari's next turn.
Blanketed in a veil of mist, an enormous, centipede-like creature sifts its way through the swamp, the severed tail of a wyvern gripped tightly within its jaws.

Whenever an unnatural mist suddenly arises, some believe it to be the sign of a kirikari. Though they're rare and solitary creatures, kirikari are considered highly dangerous due to their heightened aggression and territorial behavior.

entries.name: Ambush Predators
entries: Few can spot a kirikari in hiding, as it appears as little more than a collapsed tree concealed in fog. It then waits patiently for its prey to draw near—before striking out at them with its lightning-fast bite.

entries.name: Symbiotic Relationship
entries: The mist that covers a kirikari's body comes from a unique type of mold that adheres to its carapace. The mold secretes an acid that evaporates harmlessly shortly after being exposed to air. The kirikari uses this mist to conceal itself and disorient its prey. Despite being natural-born swimmers, kirikari tend to avoid swimming in ocean waters, as exposure to salt quickly kills its mold.

entries.name: Wyvern Hunters
entries: Though unusual for its behavior, kirikari have been known to travel incredible distances to hunt down {@creature wyvern|mm|wyverns}. Some scholars theorize that the toxins within a wyvern's body are a necessary component in the maintenance of a kirikari's mold.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The narshark has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Magical Horn
entries: The narshark's horn can be attacked and severed (AC 18; hp 5; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage) or destroyed (hp 15). If its horn is severed, the narshark loses its flying speed, loses 4 ({@damage 1d8}) hp at the start of each of its turns, and goes into a frenzy. While in a frenzy, the narshark has advantage on bite attack rolls and attack rolls against it have advantage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage. If the creature isn't an undead or a construct, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or lose 2 ({@damage 1d4}) hp at the start of each of its turns as one of the shark's teeth chips off into the wound. Any creature can take an action to stanch the wound by removing the tooth. The wound also closes and the tooth pops out if the target receives magical healing.

Almost blending in with the sky, this creature looks like a large shark with cerulean-hued skin and incredibly long pectoral fins that it uses to sail through the air like a bird. Its mouth is filled with several rows of vicious teeth, and an ivory horn emerges from the top of its head.

entries.name: Aerial Predators
entries: A narshark is a creature that resembles a cross between a shark and a narwhal with dark blue skin, long serrated teeth, and a horn growing from its brow. Like many sharks, the narshark is a rapacious predator, hunting birds through the sky as a shark hunts fish. While it lacks the keen nose of most predators, the narshark has excellent eyesight and can pick out details at great distances. While narsharks are dangerous predators, they are seldom top of the aerial food chain and face fierce competition from {@creature giant eagle|mm|giant eagles}, {@creature hippogriff|mm|hippogriffs}, and {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. They are also frequently hunted by {@creature griffon|mm|griffins}, {@creature wyvern|mm|wyverns}, and {@creature roc|mm|rocs} that easily pluck them out of the sky with their greater maneuverability and speed.

entries.name: Magical Horns
entries: The narshark gains its ability to fly from its magical horn. The horn can be severed from a living narshark, but doing so drives it into a panicked rage as it attempts to slay all those around it. Strangely, narsharks never use their horns in combat, possibly in fear of accidentally breaking them. A narshark's horn is commonly used in the creation of magic items that grant flight, and narsharks are often the target of hunters seeking to turn a profit.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the sarsaok moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 13 ({@damage 3d8}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Divine Horns
entries: The sarsaok's gore attack is magical. In addition, its gore attack ignores the target's resistances to piercing or fire damage.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: Any creature that touches the sarsaok or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sarsaok makes two attacks: one with its gore and one with its hooves.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Immolating Purge {@recharge 5}
entries: The sarsaok spews burning blood in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
This huge, six-horned, bull-like creature possesses a mane of writhing flames and shimmering metal skin.

entries.name: Creation of the Gods
entries: All sarsaok descend from Hadhayosh, a mighty celestial ox said to have been present at the creation of humanity. Scholars speculate the union of domestic or wild oxen with Hadhayosh produced the first sarsaok.

entries.name: Inhospitable Habitats
entries: The sarsaok dwell in areas of great heat and fire such as Volcanoes or other geologically active regions. In addition to consuming flora, they are known to drink liquid magma and graze on obsidian, pumice, or other volcanic rock.

entries.name: Peaceful Horror
entries: Though of great size and strength, sarsaoks are peaceful herbivores similar in demeanor to wild oxen. When threatened, an entire herd attacks until the threat has ended.

trait.name: Death Curse
entries: When the scarlet ibis dies, all curses currently inflicted by the ibis become permanent and can be removed only by the {@spell remove curse} spell or other magic.

In addition, the creature that dealt the killing blow must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or become cursed with every option listed in the ibis's beak attack. A creature casting {@spell remove curse} on a creature cursed in this way must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or suffer the curses it just removed.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The scarlet ibis makes three attacks: one with its beak and two with its talons.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or become cursed. While cursed, the target has disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, or saving throws (the scarlet ibis' choice). Alternatively, the ibis can choose for the target's enemies to have advantage on attack rolls against the target. A creature can have no more than one of each kind of curse on it at a time. The curses last for 24 hours or until removed by the {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) slashing damage.
{@i This gigantic marsh bird has blood-red feathers and a scythe-like beak. Its eyes shine with intelligence as it scans its surroundings.}
The scarlet ibis is a large bird native to the Sloefire known for their peculiar talent fatal misfortune on those they strike.

{@b Enchanted Birds.} Scarlet ibises are not inherently malevolent, and many visitors to the swamp assume they are simply overly large birds. However, their beaks bestow unluck on those touched or struck by them. The ibises usually reserve their cursed attacks as retribution for themselves, but swamp dwellers sometimes plea for the birds' intercession on those who have wronged them. Scarlet ibises have keen judgment to determine the worthiness of these requests.

Those who know about scarlet ibises and their terrible curses avoid killing the birds and typically warn others about the consequences of killing them. Less scrupulous folk instead encourage naïve travelers to destroy a scarlet ibis then pick off the travelers suffering from the aftereffects of combat with the birds.

{@b Untouchable Symbols.} Scarlet ibises are recognized as symbols of beauty and misfortune within the local lizardfolk tribe native to their home. Their dazzling crimson plumage is considered priceless to many, but the superstitious reptiles refuse to touch it in fear of the misfortune their death brings. The tribe will often observe an ibis from afar if one is spotted before offering it trinkets, which it often accepts.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The shriekbat can't use its {@sense blindsight} while {@condition deafened}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shriekbat makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its talons.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the shriekbat can't use its talons on another target.

action.name: Shriek {@recharge 5}
entries: The shriekbat emits a powerful burst of sound in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 12d6}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target is also {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A {@condition stunned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
This midnight-blue bat has a cavern-filling wingspan. The air near its mouth, large enough to carry a horse, visibly vibrates with sound pulses.

Shriekbats thrive in the cavernous spaces of the Underworld where they face little competition from dragons, rocs, and other large flying creatures, as they would aboveground. Despite their enormousness, the bats deftly maneuver among the stalactites and stalagmites crowding underground caverns. When they attack prey, or in the very rare cases where they must escape predators, they emit a terrible shriek that overwhelms their foes and allows them to easily grab prey or escape. Shriekbat echolocation uses subsonic frequencies, allowing the bats to fly in relative silence.

entries.name: Kobold Companions
entries: Kobold bat keepers know the secret to raising young shriekbats. The bat keepers often risk their lives to procure young, using the bats for protection and as companions. A bat keeper returns its shriekbat to the wild before the bat reaches adulthood, when it would become too large for the cramped kobold tunnels. A bat keeper tracks the shriekbats it releases, and often returns to visit its former companions. Shriekbats prove surprisingly keen at remembering former kobold handlers (whether such handlers treated them well or poorly), and they often allow fondly remembered handlers to take a single pup from their litters, ensuring the pup survives to adulthood and renewing the cycle.

entries.name: Long-Lived Omnivores
entries: Shriekbats live for nearly 50 years. They are social and promiscuous creatures that live in small groups in large caverns. They are omnivorous but prefer fresh meat to other food with lizards taking up the majority of their diet. Shriekbats can survive on rotten flesh, which allows them to eat ghouls and other undead populating the Underworld, but they find it less palatable. In overcrowded situations where multiple groups of shriekbats roost in the same cavern, a group of shriekbats might break away to find another hunting location if food becomes scarce.

trait.name: Iron Scent
entries: The boar can pinpoint, by scent, the location of ferrous metal within 60 feet of it.

trait.name: Lightning Hide
entries: A creature that touches the boar or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 2d4}) lightning damage.

trait.name: Relentless (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: If the boar takes 15 damage or less that would reduce it to 0 hp, it is reduced to 1 hp instead.

trait.name: Thunder Charge
entries: If the boar moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a tusk attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) thunder damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) lightning damage, and In addition, nonmagical metal armor worn by the target is partly devoured by the boar and takes a permanent and cumulative 2 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed if the penalty reduces its AC to 10.

action.name: Lightning Run {@recharge 6}
entries: The boar becomes a bolt of living lightning and moves up to its speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}. It can move through creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage and is pushed to the closest unoccupied space if it ends its turn inside an object. Each creature in the boar's path must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Thunder Leap {@recharge 6}
entries: The boar moves up to 20 feet, jumping over obstacles in its way. Difficult terrain doesn't cost it extra movement when it leaps. Each creature within 10 feet of the boar when it leaps and each creature within 10 feet of where it lands must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 16 ({@damage 3d10}) thunder damage and is pushed up to 10 feet away from the boar. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't pushed.
A massive, green-scaled boar snorts angrily as tiny bolts of blue lightning ripple over its body.

entries.name: Accidental Arcane Creations
entries: An {@creature evoker|vgm} who raised hogs to fund their wild experiments, accidentally blew up their tower years ago. The explosion created a horrific storm that raged for days in the region, causing the locals to take shelter. When the storm dissipated, the wizard and their tower were gone, but the hogs had been transformed into scaled beasts that harnessed the power of lightning and thunder.

entries.name: Storm's Fury
entries: Stormboars embody the fury of the storm. Just as stubborn and ferocious as their more mundane cousins, stormboars let no obstacle get in their way while they look for food or protect their offspring. Seasoned hunters know to drop an offering of metal behind as they leave the area to ensure the boar is too distracted to follow them.

entries.name: Metal Devourers
entries: Stormboars crave metal. Prospectors track the boars to find areas rich with precious minerals and ore, and treasure hunters use the creatures to sniff out hidden vaults of wealth. Anyone relying on a stormboar must be careful, however. The boars see any creature wearing or carrying metal as the deliverer of an easy meal. The aggressive creatures won't stop attacking until they've consumed every bit of metal an unfortunate traveler is carrying. Starving stormboars have been known to venture into civilized areas for a meal.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: In the first round of combat, the tembril has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

trait.name: Nimble Leap
entries: The tembril can take the {@action Dash} or {@action Disengage} action as a bonus action on each of its turns. In addition, the tembril can jump horizontally up to 20 feet and vertically up to 10 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tembril makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the tembril scores a critical hit against a Medium or smaller target and the damage reduces the target to below half its hp maximum, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be instantly killed as its head is removed. A creature is immune to this effect if it is immune to piercing damage or doesn't have or need a head.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Maddening Chitter {@recharge 6}
entries: The tembril chitters maddeningly in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition incapacitated} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition incapacitated}. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it also suffers {@table short-term madness}. An {@condition incapacitated} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition incapacitated} condition on itself on a success.

Standing on its back legs and holding a decapitated human head in its hands, this nightmarish creature resembles a gigantic squirrel with saber-like teeth, soulless black eyes, and hard, scaly skin. It chitters softly and eerily.

entries.name: Forest Terrors
entries: In the dark and foreboding forests of the north, tales are spun of terrible ogres, hags, evil wolves, and great arctic serpents, but humans and ogres alike fear the tembril, a savage beast that feeds specifically on the eyes, tongues, and brains of humanoids. Resembling a squirrel the size of a bear, but with brown scales and immense claws and fangs, the tembril hunts sapient fey, humanoids, and giants exclusively, using its claws to eviscerate its opponent as its teeth punctures their skulls.

entries.name: Head Collectors
entries: The victim of a tembril attack is almost always found without its head, for the creature collects the severed cranium to devour the contents either immediately or at a later time. Tembrils store the heads in the long winter months, hiding them within the hollows of great trees or in other suitable locations and covering them in ice so they don't decompose. The decapitated bodies left behind make a meal for many forest-dwelling scavengers, and {@creature crow|wdmm|crows}, {@creature worg|mm|worgs}, and even {@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls} have been known to follow in a tembril's wake, looking for a fresh feast.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The tidehunter can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Net Maker
entries: With 1 minute of work, the tidehunter can create a net out of seaweed, rope, or similar material. The tidehunter typically carries 2 net.

trait.name: Underwater Camouflage.
entries: The tidehunter has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made while underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tidehunter makes three attacks, only one of which can be with its net. It can use Reel in place of two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). The tidehunter has two claws, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Net
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}A Large or smaller creature hit by the net is {@condition restrained} until it is freed. The net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger.  A creature can use its action to make a {@dc 15} Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 15 slashing damage to the net (AC 13) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

action.name: Reel
entries: The tidehunter pulls one creature {@condition restrained} by its net up to 20 feet straight toward it. If the target is within 10 feet of the tidehunter at the end of this pull, the tidehunter can make one claw attack against it as a bonus action.

reaction.name: Entangle Weapon
entries: When the tidehunter is targeted by a melee weapon attack, the attacker must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw or miss the attack as the tidehunter uses its net to interfere with the weapon. The tidehunter must have an empty net to use this reaction.

Emerging from the surf, this massive crab-like beast has a hard, blue shell covered in barnacles. It holds a net of seaweed between its barbed claws, and a look of intelligence gleams in its elliptical, crimson eyes.

entries.name: Lurkers in the Shallows
entries: The tidehunter is an ambush hunter, using its coloration to surprise prey that venture into the shallows. Tidehunters are normally found along coasts with plentiful beaches and underwater vegetation, but some can be found in large lakes and river systems close to the open ocean. Most tidehunters are more than 20 feet across and are powerful enough to overcome a {@creature hunter shark} or small whale with ease. They have few natural predators, their intelligence and guile making them challenging prey.

entries.name: Net Weavers
entries: Tidehunters can weave nets out of kelp, seaweed, and other fibrous plant material with ease, constructing nets in a matter of minutes with the weirdly hooked barbs on their claws. Their nets are strong and can be thrown with great accuracy over a large distance. Indeed, even those on dry land are not immune to the tidehunter's attacks, and more than one human has been hauled into the surging tide from the apparent safety of the beach.

entries.name: Fishing Buddies
entries: While fisherfolk and tidehunters are normally at odds, a tidehunter will sometimes enter into an unspoken agreement with a group of fisherfolk, sharing the spoils of the sea while keeping out of each other's way.

trait.name: Distance Runner
entries: The zouyu is capable of incredibly fast long-distance travel. When traveling at a fast pace, the zouyu can run 310 miles per day.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The zouyu has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the zouyu moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the zouyu can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zouyu uses Alter Luck. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Alter Luck
entries: The zouyu flicks its vibrant, multi-stranded tail and alters the luck of one creature it can see within 30 feet of it, choosing one of the following luck options. The zouyu can't target itself with Alter Luck.

items.name: Bestow Luck.
items.entry: The target has advantage on the next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw (zouyu's choice) it makes before the end of its next turn.

items.name: Steal Luck
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on the next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw (zouyu's choice) it makes before the end of its next turn. If the target fails the saving throw, the zouyu has advantage on one attack roll or saving throw it makes before the start of its next turn.

entries: This elephant-sized feline has sleek fur, four upwardturned fangs in its mouth, and a long tail ending in multiple strands like a pheasant.

entries.name: Familial Bonds
entries: Zouyu live as mated pairs with large territories. The great felines are gentle and social creatures, often overlapping their territories for mutual protection.

entries.name: Good Luck
entries: For many, the zouyu are symbols of good luck and fortune. The tail feather of a zouyu, freely given, can be rendered into a liquid, which produces a luck potion. The potion brings minor good fortune, such as finding a fruit tree when hungry or shelter when it rains, to the drinker for a day. If a tail feather is taken without the zouyu's knowledge, the potion created by the feather bestows bad luck on the drinker for a day. Such bad luck manifests as the drinker tripping over a too-perfectly-placed rock or a lightning strike felling a tree onto the drinker's path.

trait.name: Burrow
entries: Dogmole juggernauts cannot burrow into solid rock, but they can move through softer material like soil or loose rubble, leaving a usable tunnel 10 ft. in diameter.

trait.name: Ferocity (1/Day)
entries: When the dogmole juggernaut is reduced to 0 hit points, it doesn't die until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Powerful Build
entries: A dogmole juggernaut is treated as one size larger if doing so is advantageous to it (such as during grapple checks, pushing attempts, and tripping attempts, but not for the purposes of squeezing or AC). It gains advantage against magical pushing attempts such as gust of wind or Repelling Blast.

trait.name: Wormkiller Rage
entries: Wild dogmole juggernaut packs are famed for their battles against the monsters of the dark caverns of the world. If a dogmole juggernaut draws blood against vermin, purple worms, or other underground invertebrate, it gains a +4 bonus to Strength and Constitution but suffers a −2 penalty to AC. The wormkiller rage lasts for a number of rounds equal to 1 + its Constitution modifier (minimum 1 round). It cannot end the rage voluntarily while the creatures that sent it into a rage still live.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dogmole juggernaut makes one claw attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

{@i Hide armor and scraps of mail are nailed onto this scarred and tattooed mole-like beast. A ring of tentacles sprouts above its mouth, which is dominated by spade-like incisors. The beast has no visible ears and only tiny, cataract-filled eyes. Blood and foam fleck from its tentacled maw.}

entries.name: Grown from Chaos
entries: What the derro have done with certain breeds of dogmole almost defies description, but the secret of their size is a steady diet of chaos fodder, magical foodstuffs and spells that force the creatures to grow and grow.

entries.name: Scarred and Abused
entries: Brutalized from birth and hardened by scarification, foul drugs, and warping magic, the dogmole juggernaut is barely recognizable as a relative of its smaller kin. A furless mass of muscle, scar tissue, and barbed piercings clad in haphazard barding, a dogmole juggernaut stands seven feet tall at the shoulder and stretches nine to twelve feet long. Its incisors are the length of shortswords.

entries.name: Living Siege Engines
entries: Derro use dogmole juggernauts as mounts and improvised siege engines, smashing through bulwarks and breaking up dwarven battle lines. When not at war, derro enjoy pitting rabid juggernauts against one another in frenzied gladiatorial contests.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fire goose makes two attacks with its wing blades.

action.name: Wing Blades
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fire Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The fire goose breathes fire in a 20-foot cone. Every creature in the area must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. The goose's fire breath ignites flammable objects and melts soft metals in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

reaction.name: Final "Fuck You"
entries: When the fire goose is reduced to 0 hit points, it can use its last breath to emit a horrendous cacophony of screams directly from the tortured souls of the lower planes. Creatures within 20 feet that can hear the goose must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} for 1 round. A creature {@condition incapacitated} in this way has its speed reduced to 0.
{@i This goose-like creature's feathers are razor sharp like shining metal. When it inhales, the feathers on its chest glow red hot.}

Fire geese are malevolent, deadly creatures originating from the Lower Planes. They grow feathers like their Material Plane counterparts, but their feathers are rigid and sharp like gleaming, edged metal.

{@b Ferrivorous Feathers.} The plumage of a fire goose displays a stunning mixture of metallic colors, which vary depending on their diet. The fire goose uses its fire breath to melt metals with low melting points such as gold, silver, lead, copper, and bronze, along with the orphanages. The fire goose consumes the molten metal, some of which migrates into the creature's deadly feathers. Fire geese that display primarily or entirely a single color are highly prized, but dangerous to capture.

{@b Malevolent Pseudo-Demons.} Like most geese, the fire goose is an irritable and aggressive creature, but unlike its mundane kin, the fire goose is blazingly malevolent, taking to the skies and melting towns and villages like a miniature dragon. Despite its small stature, it’s surprisingly dangerous and extremely confrontational.

trait.name: Ghostwalk
entries: As a bonus action, the ghostwalk spider becomes {@condition invisible} and intangible. Attacking doesn't end this invisibility. While {@condition invisible}, the ghostwalk spider has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks and gains the following:
Damage Resistances acid, cold, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical weapons
Condition Immunities {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition petrified}, {@condition prone}, {@condition restrained}, {@condition stunned}
The ghostwalk ends when the spider chooses to end it as a bonus action or when the spider dies.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement (During Ghostwalk Only)
entries: The ghostwalk spider can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ghostwalk spider makes two bite attacks. It can make a ghostly snare attack in place of one of its bites.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) poison damage, or half poison damage with a successful {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} and {@condition paralyzed} for 1 hour, even after regaining hit points. While using Ghostwalk, the spider's bite and poison do half damage to targets that aren't affected by Ghostly Snare (see below).

action.name: Ghostly Snare (During Ghostwalk Only, Recharge 5–6)
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 40/160 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition restrained} by ghostly webbing. While {@condition restrained} in this way, the target is {@condition invisible} to all creatures except ghostwalk spiders, and it has resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, and thunder damage. A creature {@condition restrained} by Ghostly Snare can escape by using an action to make a successful {@dc 14} Strength check, or the webs can be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5).
{@i A pasty-white spider the size of a horse slinks through the shadows. Its dull eyes fix on you as it fades from sight with a ghostly blue shimmer.}

Ghostwalk spiders are malevolent hunters that sprang from misguided experiments on phase spiders. They are spindly, emaciated things all but devoid of color. The spider is 8 feet in diameter (including legs) and weighs 500 pounds.

entries.name: Phantom Webs
entries: Ghostwalk spiders spin ephemeral webs in secluded areas. They spend most of their time stalking prey to paralyze and drag back to their phantom web. As long as these remains lie tangled in ghostly webs they go unnoticed by material creatures, but the spiders eventually cast old kills aside. Adventurers are wise to fear empty caves containing unexplained, desiccated remains.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The colossal squid can hold its breath for 1 hour.

trait.name: Jet
entries: While underwater, the colossal squid can take the dash action to jet backward at a speed of 140 feet. It must move in a straight line while using this ability.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The colossal squid can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The colossal squid makes eight tentacle attacks and one bite attack. It can substitute two tentacles attacks for one constrict attack if it has a creature {@condition grappled} at the start of its turn, but it never constricts more than once per turn.

action.name: Mangling Mandibles
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 5d8 + 7}) slashing damage. This attack scores a critical hit on a target that is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 1d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d6}) slashing damage. If two tentacle attacks hit the same target in one turn, the target is also {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}).

action.name: Constrict
entries: The constricted creature takes 26 ({@damage 3d12 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}) and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Ink Cloud {@recharge}
entries: The colossal squid emits black, poisonous ink in a 30-foot cloud as a bonus action while underwater. The cloud affects vision as the darkness spell, and any creature that starts its turn inside the cloud takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage, or half damage with a successful {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. The colossal squid's {@sense darkvision} is not impaired by this cloud. The cloud persists for 1 minute, then disperses.

action.name: Vomit Forth the Deeps (1/Day)
entries: The colossal squid sprays half-digested food from its maw over a 15-foot cone. This acidic slurry causes 18 ({@damage 5d6}) acid damage and targets must make a successful {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of their next turn.

Colossal squids traverse the depths of the sea, usually unseen by the common sailor. With eight muscular arms and two long tentacles, these creatures could be mistaken for the offspring of a Great Olde One. On very rare occasions, these animals travel to the surface of the sea, often giving rise to tales of krakens in the area. In actuality, it’s in order to escape their natural predator, the sperm whale.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The mahoru can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The mahoru has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The mahoru has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the mahoru's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The mahoru has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that isn't at maximum hit points.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Roar
entries: When a mahoru roars all creatures with hearing within 30 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of the mahoru's next turn. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it's also {@condition paralyzed} for the same duration. A target that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the Roar of all mahoru for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Vorpal Bite
entries: A mahoru's saw-like jaws excel at dismembering prey. When the mahoru scores a critical hit, the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or lose an appendage. Roll {@dice 1d12} on the following table for the result:
1–2: right hand
3–4: left hand
5–6: right foot
7–8: left foot
9: right forearm
10: left forearm
11: right lower leg
12: left lower leg

{@i I saw no more terrible beast on all my journeys north than the mahoru. The white bears had their aloof majesty, the lindwurm serpentine grace, but the monster that gnawed away the pack ice beneath our feet and savaged any who fell into the water was a thing of nightmare. The men it snatched were torn apart, like rags in the mouth of a rabid dog.}
A hybrid of fish and mammal, a mahoru is eight feet long and looks like a small orca with a serpentine neck and seal-like head.

entries.name: Valuable Teeth and Fur
entries: Their heavy jaws are filled with triangular, serrated teeth adept at tearing flesh and sundering bone. Their white and black fur is highly prized for its warmth and waterproof qualities. Their pectoral fins feature stubby, claw-tipped paws. Skraeling use the mahoru's fangs to make arrowheads or tooth-studded clubs, and the mahoru is a totem beast for many northern tribes.

entries.name: Iceberg Hunters
entries: Relatives of the bunyip, mahoru prowl northern coasts and estuaries, hunting among the fragmenting pack ice each summer. They lurk beneath the surface, catching swimmers chunks or lurching up onto the ice to break or tilt it and send prey tumbling into the water.
