Transitioning to a more terrestrial lifestyle, these rogue males claim large territories, ranging anywhere from 20 to 40 square miles. They defend these territories ferociously, patrolling them vigilantly. They are nocturnal predators, behaving similarly to will-o-wisps. They will lure unsuspecting travelers and other creatures close enough to be shocked and devoured. In fact, in areas where will-o’-wisps are present, the rogue males will often mistake their lights for a challenging male, charging towards the tiny undead with immense prejudice.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The peacock can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components. The peacock's spellcasting ability is Charisma (Spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit) when casting these spells.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The peacock doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Two-Headed
entries: The peacock has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Void Dweller
entries: The cosmic peacock dwells in the empty expanse between the stars, and does not require air, food, drink, or sleep. When flying between stars the cosmic peacock magically glides on solar winds, making the immense journey through the void in an impossibly short time.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The peacock makes three attacks; two with its bite and one with its talons.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the peacock can't use its talons on another target.

action.name: Breath Weapons {@recharge 5}
entries: The peacock uses one of the following breath weapons. The right head exhales gravitic breath and stellar flare breath, while the left head exhales void breath and paralyzing breath. Both heads can use a breath weapon individually, even when the other head needs to recharge.

{@bold Gravitic Breath.} The right head exhales a 60-foot cube of powerful localized gravity, originating from the bird. Falling damage in the area increases to {@dice 1d10} per 10 feet fallen. When a creature starts its turn within the area or enters it for the first time in a turn, including when the peacock creates the field, must make a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw. On a failure the creature is {@condition restrained}. On a success the creature's speed is halved as long as it remains in the field. A {@condition restrained} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn. The field persists until the right head's breath recharges, and it can't use gravitic breath twice consecutively.

{@bold Stellar Flare Breath.} The right head exhales star fire in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 31 ({@damage 9d6}) fire damage and 31 ({@damage 9d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

{@bold Void Breath.} The left head exhales a frigid sliver of the void in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw, taking 58 ({@damage 13d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

{@bold Paralyzing Breath.} The left head exhales paralyzing gas in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

{@italic In the depths of the cosmos, a polycephalic peacock seemingly composed of various celestial bodies  soars vigilantly through the stars. Each individual feather composing its magnificent tail gleams like miniature suns in the darkness of the void.}

{@bold Galactic Guardian:} The Cosmic Peacock is a timeless being that soars through the emptiness of space in search of potential major threats to sentient life, including black holes, supernovas, and, more recently, undead demigods. It protects the lives of those it deems worthy, risking its own for the sake of theirs.

{@bold Cosmic Power:} The Cosmic Peacock attacks with the full fury of the cosmos, bending the stars to its whim.  While its physical prowess is certainly astonishing, it’s truly revered for its command over the most potent weapon in the universe; space.

{@bold Two Heads are Better than One:} The Peacock is polycephalic, or two-headed. The two heads seem to bicker often, possessing separate observable personalities. With the left head acting erratic and spontaneous while the right is calm and level-headed, the two heads act like two sides of the same coin, although both fight for the safety of others. The left head commands the chilling aspects of the void whilst the right commands gravity and light. When acting in unison, the two heads can be truly devastating to anything that opposes them.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The whale's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution. It can innately cast the following spells (spell save {@dc 19}), requiring no material components:
will: {@spell create or destroy water} (90 gallons; rains approximately 5,335,923,600 gallons)

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the whale hits with it (included in the attack).

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The whale can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The whale can hold its breath for 90 minutes.

trait.name: Flooded
entries: Any space that has been flooded by one of the whale's actions is filled with two to three feet of water, and it is difficult terrain for any creature without an innate or magical swimming speed. The flooded areas remain flooded for 24 hours, until the whale absorbs the water, or until it is turned to steam.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The whale has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the whale fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Cackling
entries: The skeleton of Captain Ahab cackles madly, disorienting each creature that can hear him and isn’t {@condition incapacitated}. Each creature that starts its turn within 20 feet of the whale and can hear the cackling must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature can't take reactions until the start of its next turn and begins to hallucinate, becoming afflicted with a short-term madness effect (determined randomly or by the DM). The effect lasts 10 minutes and the target can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The whale makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 5d8 + 8}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the whale. A swallowed creature has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the whale, and it takes 3 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the whale's turns. If the whale takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the whale must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the whale. If the whale dies, a swallowed creature can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d6 + 8}) bludgeoning damage, or 44 ({@damage 8d6 + 16}) bludgeoning damage if the target is an object.

action.name: Tidal Wave
entries: The whale conjures up a wave of water that crashes down on an area in front of it. The area can be up to 30 feet long, up to 10 feet wide, and up to 10 feet tall. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone} on a failed save, or half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} on a successful one. The water then spreads out 15 feet across the ground in all directions, flooding the area.

action.name: Maelstrom
entries: The water in a 30-foot radius around the whale is pulled towards it and absorbed into its body, increasing its AC by 2 until the end of its next turn. Each creature in flooded terrain must make a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or take 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and be pulled 10 feet toward the whale on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one and is not pulled.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The whale uses a tail attack.

legendary.name: Charge (Uses 2 Actions)
entries: The whale moves up to its speed in a straight line without provoking opportunity attacks. Any creature or object caught in its path must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save and being pushed 10 feet away from the whale. On a successful save, the target is not affected by this attack.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The whale makes a perception check.

In most sea-faring cultures, tales about epic battles between brave sailors and massive leviathans are incorporated so deeply within their society that, as time goes on, some believe the legends of heroism and adventure to be accurate recounts of the sea, and thus embark on epic quests to search for and slay dangerous nautical fiends. In most cases, these stories truly are just myth, but in one of the most famous tales of all, the beast recounted was a true demon. Moby Dick, the White Whale, is an ancient predator that stalks the seas in search of whaling ships to destroy so that it may devour the blood of man to feed its insatiable appetite for flesh. Resembling a massive sperm whale with an enormous, toothed maw, the White Whale commands the sea to its whim, and is capable of conjuring colossal waves at will. Occasionally, it will create massive tsunamis in order to sweep inland, carrying warm flesh out to sea where it can be easily devoured. Several harpoons are embedded within its thick hide, and a skeleton ensnared to its back cackles madly.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The stag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the golden stag moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one {@condition prone} creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

{@italic As Helvetica lie, helpless and dying, her companions could do nothing more than comfort her in her final moments. As her breathing became shallow, her friends knew she was nearing her last. Before she had the chance to take in her final breath, an elk cloaked in a golden sheen stepped out of the thick fog, approaching the group like a noble ruler. Wordlessly, the party allowed the animal to approach Helvetica, where it gently enveloped her with its crown of golden antlers. A dim, radiant light poured from the beast’s royal circlet of bone, and within moments, Helvetica stretched her limbs casually as if awoken from a deep slumber.}

Golden stags are magical cousins to elk and other cervids. It is an avid protector of the animals in its forest, often coming to their rescue. A golden stag is also sympathetic to those who get lost in its woods or seem to struggle with survival in the cold. The creature beckons unfortunate travelers to follow it to safety, often just outside a village it knows to be friendly. If a visitor to a forest overseen by a golden stag has a peaceful encounter with the creature, the stag might later come to that visitor's aid, protecting it from predatory animals or rescuing it from some natural hazard. Additionally, the golden stag commands some innate healing ability, using it to heal the sick, wounded, or dying. Many desperate travelers bring loved ones to forests inhabited by golden stags in hope of receiving help from the forest guardian.

trait.name: Bad Flier
entries: The storm chicken falls at the end of its turn if it's airborne and the only thing holding it aloft is its flying speed.

trait.name: Call of the Storm
entries: The storm chicken can cast {@spell control weather} at will, requiring no material components and requiring only one action to cast, in which the storm chicken crows into the ether above, pleading for the dark gods to answer its malevolent cry.

action.name: Peck
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft, one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d1 + 2}) piercing damage.

{@italic Villagers scramble about a lively town square, busily going about their daily lives. They were grateful for such a beautiful day, as the past week had been dreary and gray. Disgusted by the joy of it all, an average-looking rooster perches upon a fencepost, observing the people as they enjoyed the simplicity of life. The bird crowed loudly, emitting a hoarse, cackling call. The townsfolk, too preoccupied with their own existences, paid the chicken no mind. Laughing to itself, the malevolent little rooster knew that in just a few minutes, the clear blue sky would be crowded with puffy gray clouds, threatening to fill the surrounding area with a light drizzle. This day would be regarded as a minor annoyance by many.}

Alright, first of all, screw the formalities. I made this thing late at night because I was bored and wanted to make a powerful little chicken monster. So basically, I made this malevolent little bastard. He looks like a regular rooster, but he actually is a malicious little monstrosity thing that can control the very weather with his crow, which is hoarse as {@italic fuck}. So he goes around and makes beautiful days shitty so that he can dance atop the sorrows of people. Busy day? Rain. Wedding? Rain. Party? Rain. This deep fried little shit is the lord of minor inconveniences. Also, he can control the literal fucking weather, so don’t piss him off. He will tornado your house.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ursa polaris' innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 15}, +7 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The ursa polaris has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The ursa polaris can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The ursa polaris has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Rime
entries: An area covered in rime is difficult terrain. Additionally, any creature that ends its turn while touching a frost covered area takes 4 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage and is {@condition grappled} by the frost (escape {@dc 16}).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bear makes three attacks; one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d8 + 7}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Icewind Gale {@recharge 5}
entries: The ursa polaris exhales an icy blast of freezing wind in a 60-foot cone. The area is covered in rime for 1 minute and each creature in that area must a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 8d6}) cold damage on a failed save. Additionally, the creature magically begins to freeze and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} until freed by the greater restoration spell or other magic. It can't be thawed and is immune to all damage and conditions until freed. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition petrified}.

{@italic Thick, white fur coats this hulking ursine, and massive crystalline shards of ice protrude from its shoulders. When it lets out a mighty roar, frigid breath dances between the jagged sprouts of ice that form its teeth.}

A fearsome sight, the ursa polaris dwarfs even the largest of polar bears. Some believe that they are polar bears blessed or cursed by gods of cold, winter, and the north. Followers of such gods often leave a caribou carcass, whale blubber, or seal meat as an offering to the ursa polaris.

{@bold Creatures of Ice.}The ursa polaris thrives in freezing arctic conditions and is capable of surviving off of ice alone, should other food sources become scarce. They dislike warmth; an ursa polaris will avoid warm waters and curl into its ice cavern when summer comes.

{@bold Fiercely Territorial. }The ursa polaris is a solitary creature, carving a vast swath of territory for itself and going out of its way to kill trespassers. Somewhere within its territory, a female ursa polaris will carve out an ice cavern to rear young; this cavern may be within glacial ice, an iceberg, or simply a frosty stone cavern.
{@bold Icy Breath. }The ursa polaris can exhale a fragment of frigid arctic winds, disabling prey and cocooning them in rime for an easy kill.

trait.name: Ingrain
entries: The venusaur regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point remaining. If the venusaur takes fire damage before the start of its next turn, this trait doesn't function until the beginning of its next turn.

trait.name: Leaves' Edge
entries: The venusaur can forego its multiattack to extend the range of its razor leaf to 50 feet.

trait.name: Photosynthesis
entries: Whenever the venusaur is subjected to radiant damage, it takes no damage and regains a number of hit points equal to the radiant damage dealt.

trait.name: Chlorophyll (1/Day)
entries: The first time the venusaur drops below half of its maximum hit points (131), the massive corpse flower atop its back blooms for 10 minutes, giving it the following benefits:
- The venusaur's save DC's are increased by 1.
- The hit points regained by its ingrain trait increases to 10 hit points at the start of its turn.
- It gains the use of Solar Beam (see actions).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The venusaur attacks twice with its vine whip and once with its razor leaf.

action.name: Vine Whip
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. Alternatively, the venusaur can choose to grapple the target (escape {@dc 18}). While {@condition grappled} in this way, the target is {@condition restrained}. While {@condition restrained}, the venusaur can automatically hit a target with its vine whip and can move the {@condition grappled} creature up to 30 feet in any direction as a bonus action.

action.name: Razor Leaf
entries: The venusaur shakes loose a deadly shower of slicing leaves. Each creature within 15 feet of the venusaur must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Giga Drain {@recharge 5}
entries: The venusaur chooses one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 5d10}) necrotic damage on a failed save. Additionally, the venusaur regains HP equal to half the damage dealt to the target as it saps the moisture from it. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and the venusaur isn't healed.

action.name: Sleeping Toxins {@recharge}
entries: The venusaur releases a cloud of poisonous, strength-sapping pollen. Each creature within 15 feet of the venusaur must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) poison damage on a failed save and become {@condition poisoned} for 10 minutes. While {@condition poisoned} this way, the target falls {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. It wakes up if it takes damage or if a creature uses an action to shake it awake. Waking up doesn't end the {@condition poisoned} condition. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}.

action.name: Solar Beam (Chlorophyll; Recharge 7-8)
entries: The venusaur harnesses solar energy, causing a pillar of brilliant scorching sunlight touch down at a point the venusaur can see within a range of 120 feet in 10-foot-radius, 100-foot-high cylinder. Bright light fills the cylinder and illuminates the area in a 30-foot-radius. When a creature enters the column's space for the first time on a turn or ends its turn there, it is engulfed by searing light, and it must make a Constitution saving throw ({@dc 19}) It takes 77 ({@damage 14d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

If a creature drops to 0 hit points while within the column's space, it turns into dust. The column persists for {@dice 1d4} rounds, during which the venusaur can move the cylinder up to 30 feet as a bonus action.

{@italic Wading through a murky river, a squat, green therapsid claws at the soil in search of roots while a massive flower atop its back blooms, emitting an alluring aroma, attracting several insects to the area. The insects climb into the plant before falling into the acidic liquid inside, providing more nutrients for the flower and its host.}

The masters of symbiosis, venusaurs are stout, robust therapsids that are equal parts plant and beast. These swamp dwellers utilize both aspects of their physiology to become apex omnivores, rivaling loxorosas, hippos, buffalos, and blastoises for the role of swampland heavyweight.

{@bold Symbiotic Mastery.} A symbiotic plant is housed on a venusaur’s back, given to each infant (called a bulbasaur) upon birth. Both organisms have evolved to depend absolutely upon the other for survival. The plant, fully linked to the muscular and nerve systems of the venusaur, gains mobility and a steady access of nutrients. The host is afforded protection by the plant’s formidable array of toxic spores, muscular vines, razor-sharp leaves, and energy manipulation. The plant pierces most of the venusaur’s organs and essential organ systems with roots, allowing it to register sensory information that the host is experiencing. There is no recorded account of a Bulbasaur surviving past infancy without it parasite, and subsequently no evidence that the tumor-like bulb can persist without a host.

{@bold Omnivorous Heavyweights}. Venusaurs require immense amounts of energy to function, so, as a result, venusaurs are the ultimate omnivores. Venusaurs have adapted to being able to feed on carrion, terrestrial flesh, fish, insects, plant matter, and even energy from the sun. As a direct result, venusaurs are only found where sustenance is abundant, and are solitary creatures. Venusaurs are extremely gluttonous creatures, akin to a bear in terms of aggressiveness. Usually, these animals are quite docile and even friendly at times, but the moment food is involved, a venusaur will lash out with its powerful vines and crush a creature into a pulp, no matter what its previous relationship was to the creature.

{@bold Noble’s Bane.} Druids are oftentimes avid fans of venusaurs, as they are a symbiotic mix of two of the most prominent and successful organisms in nature. A bond between a druid and a venusaur is special, as both the host and the parasite trust and admire their druid companion, defending them from any perceived threat with extreme hostility. In contrast, nobles will occasionally keep venusaurs as pets to be displayed in their gardens, which more often than not follows with the venusaur devouring all of the noble’s additional plants. Even worse, when the venusaur’s food supply has been depleted in its enclosure, it will use its vines and leaves to tear its way to freedom, searching for more food to devour. As of now, there is no known method for quelling a venusaur’s tremendous appetite, and so it seems nobles will remain without their prized centerpieces.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder balloon spider's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Adjust Density
entries: As a bonus action, the elder balloon spider can magically alter the weight of one object or creature that it can see within 30 feet of it if the object or creature is Huge or smaller, including itself. The target's weight is halved or doubled for up to 1 minute. While the weight of a creature is halved by this effect, the creature's speed increases by 20 feet, it can jump three times as far as normal, and it has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws. While the weight of a creature is doubled by this effect, the creature's speed is reduced by 20 feet, its jump distance is halved, its attacks deal an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage, and it has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.

trait.name: Erratic Discharge
entries: A creature or object that starts its turn within 15 feet of the elder balloon spider must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 2 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage and can move or take an action on its turn, but not both. Additionally, it falls under the effects of the levitate spell until the end of its next turn. On a success, the creature takes half damage, can take actions normally, and does not begin to levitate.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The elder balloon spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder balloon spider uses its reel in. It then makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Charged Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 40/80 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) by strands of charged webbing and begins to hover off the ground. Until this grapple ends, the target takes 6 lightning damage at the start of each of its turns and is retrained. In addition, the {@condition grappled} target can make a {@dc 16} Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to manipulate the strands of webbing and fly 10 feet in any direction.

action.name: Reel In
entries: The elder balloon spider reels in all creatures {@condition grappled} by its webbing up to 15 feet toward it. If this movement pulls the creature within 5 feet of the balloon spider, the spider can make one bite attack against the creature as a free action.

action.name: Event Horizon {@recharge}
entries: The elder balloon spider expels a burst of powerful localized gravity in a 30 foot radius, originating from the balloon spider. Falling damage in the area increases to {@dice 1d10} per 10 feet fallen. When a creature starts its turn within the area or enters it for the first time in a turn, including when the spider creates the field, it must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure the creature is {@condition restrained}. On a success the creature's speed is halved as long as it remains in the field. A {@condition restrained} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn. The field persists until the spider's event horizon recharges.

reaction.name: Gravitic Manipulation
entries: When another creature within 60 feet of the elder balloon spider, including itself, hits or is hit with a weapon attack, the balloon spider can use its reaction to increase or decrease the attack's velocity, causing the attack's target to take an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) damage or reduce the damage dealt by 11 ({@dice 2d10}).
Alternatively, if a creature within 60 feet of the spider takes damage from a fall, including itself, the spider can use its reaction to increase or reduce the fall's damage by 16 ({@dice 3d10}).

variant.name: Overcharged
entries: On extremely rare occasions, some balloon spiders can become overcharged with electricity, granting them a powerful physique and far more devastating abilities.

Balloon spiders are often captured or killed by those looking to collect their prized webbing, but those who manage to survive until maturity undergo a molting process that makes their chitinous flesh thicker and more conductive, allowing them to more effectively manipulate the electromagnetic fields that surround them. These elder balloon spiders grow to the size of horses and are capable of controlling electromagnetic forces and even gravity itself. Their nests often defy the natural forces of gravity and are considered cursed by some.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The overcharged balloon spider's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 19}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Adjust Density
entries: As a bonus action, the overcharged balloon spider can magically alter the weight of one object or creature that it can see within 50 feet of it if the object or creature is Gargantuan or smaller, including itself. The target's weight is halved, doubled, or nullified for up to 1 minute. While the weight of a creature is halved by this effect, the creature's speed increases by 20 feet, it can jump three times as far as normal, and it has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws. While the weight of a creature is doubled by this effect, the creature's speed is reduced by 20 feet, its jump distance is halved, its attacks deal an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage, and it has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws. While the weight of a creature is nullified, its attacks deal 3 ({@damage 1d6}) less damage and it is afflicted by the levitate spell, with no maximum range.

trait.name: Erratic Discharge
entries: A creature or object that starts its turn within 30 feet of the overcharged balloon spider must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) lightning damage and can move or take an action on its turn, but not both. Additionally, it falls under the effects of the levitate spell for 1 minute. On a success, the creature takes half damage, can take actions normally, and does not begin to levitate.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The overcharged balloon spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Magnetic Eruption
entries: When the overcharged balloon spider is killed, it explodes in a swath of electromagnetic destruction. Each creature and object within 60 feet of the balloon spider takes 27 ({@damage 5d10}) lightning damage and 27 ({@damage 5d10}) force damage. In addition, if the target is a creature, the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or be affected by the levitate spell, in which the target rises to a maximum altitude of 100 feet for 1 minute.

trait.name: Magnetic Surge
entries: Using a bonus action, the overcharged balloon spider can harness the magnetic field surrounding it to repulse or attract metallic objects. Any creature within 30 feet of the balloon spider wielding any material made substantially of metal must succeed on a {@dc 19} Strength saving throw or drop any metallic weapons and, if they are wearing metallic armor, be knocked {@condition prone}. Unattended metallic objects and {@condition prone} creatures are then moved in a straight line directly toward or away from the balloon spider depending on whether the spider chose to repulse or attract them. If the balloon spider chose to repulse, creatures and objects come to a stop 30 feet away from the spider. If the balloon spider chose to attract, creatures and objects are pulled onto the spider's back where they stick magnetically. A creature pulled onto a balloon spider's back is {@condition restrained} and must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 15 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage. A creature may use its action to pull itself, another creature, or an object free of the balloon spider's back by making a successful {@dc 19} Strength check. Any objects and creatures are automatically released the next time the marauder uses its ability to repulse.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder balloon spider uses its reel in twice. It then makes two bite attacks and a charged web attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Charged Web
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 40/80 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}) by strands of charged webbing and begins to hover off the ground. Until this grapple ends, the target takes 12 lightning damage at the start of each of its turns and is retrained. In addition, the {@condition grappled} target can make a {@dc 19} Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to manipulate the strands of webbing and fly 10 feet in any direction.

action.name: Reel In
entries: The overcharged balloon spider reels in all creatures {@condition grappled} by its webbing up to 25 feet toward it. If this movement pulls the creature within 5 feet of the balloon spider, the spider can make one bite attack against the creature as a free action.

action.name: Event Horizon {@recharge}
entries: The overcharged balloon spider expels a burst of powerful localized gravity in a 30 foot radius, originating from the balloon spider. Falling damage in the area increases to {@dice 2d6} per 10 feet fallen. When a creature starts its turn within the area or enters it for the first time in a turn, including when the spider creates the field, it must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure the creature is {@condition restrained}. On a success the creature's speed is halved as long as it remains in the field. A {@condition restrained} creature repeats the saving throw at the end of its turn. The field persists until the spider's event horizon recharges.

reaction.name: Gravitic Manipulation
entries: When another creature within 60 feet of the overcharged balloon spider, including itself, hits or is hit with a weapon attack, the balloon spider can use its reaction to increase or decrease the attack's velocity, causing the attack's target to take an extra 16 ({@damage 3d10}) damage or reduce the damage dealt by 16 ({@dice 3d10}). In addition, the spider can choose to give the attack advantage or disadvantage if it is made primarily of metal.
Alternatively, if a creature within 60 feet of the spider takes damage from a fall, including itself, the spider can use its reaction to increase or reduce the fall's damage by 22 ({@dice 4d10}).

Under extremely rare circumstances, a balloon spider may become overcharged when molting. This often occurs when the spider begins the process in an area with extremely high electromagnetic force, which alters its growth. These arachnids are much larger and more attuned to electromagnesis than their smaller counterparts, allowing them to command even time itself in certain intervals. These creatures claim extensive territories and will occasionally cocoon entire towns in order to make a suitable lair.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The kirin's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The kirin is an 18th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). The kirin has the following spells prepared:

trait.name: Command Lightning
entries: At the end of each of its turns, the kirin can choose three locations to be affected by the {@spell call lightning} spell. The lightning strikes at the beginning of its next turn.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the kirin fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The kirin has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The kirin's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kirin makes three attacks, two with its hooves and one with its horn.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Horn
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) lightning damage.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: The kirin makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Smite
entries: The kirin makes an attack with its hooves or casts thunderclap.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The kirin moves up to its speed without provoking attacks of opportunity.

{@italic The mythic Kirin resembles a unicorn, though closer inspection reveals that it is covered in rigid scales rather than a coat. Its majestic white mane and hair stand on end, as if charged with static. The equine beast often crackles with stray electricity.}

Kirin have radiant white fur used for collecting and effectively harnessing electricity. When a sufficient number of electrical currents have been accumulated, the Kirin will glow brightly, discharging vast amounts of electricity from its conductive hide, which will deflect almost all attacks. A Kirin's most vital feature, though, is its long, jagged horn. This horn is used to summon lightning from the sky, even when there isn't a storm cloud in sight. However, even if this horn is destroyed, Kirin are still capable of summoning lightning bolts with little effort.

Some of the more elusive, ancient, or plainly more potent individuals are known for having unusually strong electrical powers that are yet to be fully understood. Some of the larger, more powerful muscles are located in its legs, capable of delivering deadly kicks. Equipped with such powerful legs, all Kirin possess the ability to run at speeds so unexpectedly fast they appear to teleport, leaving behind a trail of blue, crackling electricity.

Kirin are as highly unpredictable as the lightning they harness. At times Kirin are tranquil, peaceful creatures, willing to share their chosen territory with large predators, while at others they are highly aggressive and territorial, trampling even mice if they so much as disturb the animal. In a distant legend, it was said that a Kirin destroyed an entire village simply because it made far too much noise for the irritable beast.

spellcasting.name: Techniques
headerEntries: The charizard has a powerful fire and air-oriented pool of abilities, all of which can be channeled at will. These abilities, called techniques or "moves," are similar to some spells, making the charizard akin to a 12th-level spellcaster, although it does not require components of any kind to cast these spells. Its technique ability is Constitution (move save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with moves). The charizard has the following techniques prepared:

trait.name: Blaze
entries: All fire damage dealt by the charizard ignores fire resistance but not fire immunity.

trait.name: Mega Evolve (1/Day)
entries: When the charizard falls under half of its maximum hit points (71), it is enveloped in a brilliant flash of light, emerging as a blazing dragon embodying fire itself. It gains the following benefits for 10 minutes:
- It loses its damage vulnerabilities and gains resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.
- It is constantly under the effects of the {@spell investiture of flame} and {@spell haste} spells.

- It regains all of its missing spell slots and can use any of its techniques without expending a spell slot. Additionally, it no longer needs to concentrate on spells that inflict fire or radiant damage.
Whenever the Charizard uses a technique that inflicts either fire or radiant damage, it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage as it saps its life force away to provide fuel for its burning fury.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The charizard doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The charizard makes one fire fang attack and two air slash attacks. It can replace any of these with an attack from its dragon tail.

action.name: Fire Fang
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Air Slash
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 50/100 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Dragon Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Fusion Flare {@recharge 5}
entries: The charizard exhales a scorching gout of fire in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) fire damage, or half as much damage with a successful {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw.

{@italic “As molten rock and magma drip from the exposed mouth of the erupting volcano, the village’s inhabitants flee in terror. The local volcano, Mt. Chimney, had shown no recent signs of activity, and its dormancy was a well-known fact. While most villagers fled, screaming and salvaging as little as they could, a select few stood among their burning home, staring up at the mighty volcano. Pointing and yelling, they managed to quell the startled villagers just long enough for them to just barely make out a large winged figure curtained by the ash and smoke. Two powerful wings kept it aloft, beating powerfully as it surveyed its burning surroundings. A burning flame danced atop the end of its long, muscular tail, scorching as brightly and powerfully as it ever had. The people knew this creature. A being, slumbering eternally in the pits of the volcano, a dragon of fire and woe. The false king, Charizard, was here to erase their village from history as punishment for its imprisonment.” – A passage from an Epic, ”The Radiant King”}

Stories such as these are cited frequently when referring to a charizard, although they couldn’t be further from the truth. Charizards are not dragons, although most seem to think so and it isn’t difficult to see why. These reptilian creatures have bright, blazing orange scales decorating a muscular, crocodilian body. A saurian head sits atop a long, veiny neck followed by a set of massive, powerful wings. A lizard-like tail drags along behind it, an everlasting flame perched at its tip.

{@bold Volcano Dwellers.} Charizards are constantly mistaken for true dragons due to their appearance, their magical potential, and their habit of lairing in volcanic regions. A charizard nests deep within the bowels of a volcano, where the temperatures are high enough to burn flesh. While normally solitary, charizards mate for life, often around the age of 40. From there, they raise up to two to three clutches of eggs for the remainder of their lifetimes, which is usually another 70 years. The laid eggs are extremely heat resistant and hatch after about 3 months, resulting in small, theropod-like reptiles known as Combustia salamandra, or charmanders. The two charizards will alternate between which adult will leave the nest to hunt, which occurs about once a week.

{@bold Blazing Predators.} When hunting, charizards will travel up to 30 miles away from their lairs in order to gather food. Being hypercarnivores, charizards prey on anything they can safely scorch from a distance, preferring moderately sized, slow prey that they can pelt with gouts of fire and compressed crescents of razor-sharp wind quickly and without injury. Charizards are not above preying upon humanoids and are intelligent enough to recognize a humanoid dwelling. However, they often stay away from slaying humanoids, as they know revenge bands may form and hunt them down.

{@bold Technical Talents.} From the moment of birth, charizards are born with a wide array of techniques and abilities, making them nearly as versatile as some spellcasters. Adults will nudge their offspring towards their full potential, teaching them to exhale fire and command it along with harness the sky to their whim. It’s heavily speculated that these techniques are a primordial form of spellcasting, making charizards one of the most ancient species on the planet. Their full array of abilities is yet to be documented, but from what is understood, they are capable of conjuring meteors from the heavens, directing the wind and sky, transforming and altering flame to fit their needs, conjuring barriers of force, and altering their own molecular composition to better suit their situation.

{@bold Flaming Fury:} Charizards fear humanoids for one reason: they are smart enough to plan and malicious enough to vow revenge. Charizards, too, are capable of revenge, and if a Charizard were to return from a hunt to a slain mate and hatchlings, it will fly into an overwhelming rage. Without thinking, it will journey to the nearest humanoid city or town and envelop it in mourning flames. When wounded, it will channel the radiant energy of the stars, being suddenly enveloped by a ball of flame and gas, which bursts outwards into a swath of brilliant celestial light. Trading its orange hide for one of endless darkness, deep blue flames spill from the sides of its jaws in a blazing inferno. As the hottest star burns twice as bright, it also burns half as long. Siphoning its own life force to enhance its attacks, a charizard only enters this form when it is hellbent on putting an end to whatever unfortunate soul decided to wound it so.

trait.name: Resistant Carapace
entries: The blastoise has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sturdy
entries: The blastoise has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition paralyzed} or {@condition stunned}. In addition, it adds its Constitution modifier to its Armor Class instead of its Dexterity modifier.

trait.name: Stable
entries: Whenever an effect knocks the blastoise {@condition prone}, it can make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw to avoid being knocked {@condition prone}. A {@condition prone} blastoise is upside down. To stand up, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity check on its turn and then use all its movement for that turn.

trait.name: Defense Curl
entries: Instead of moving, the blastoise can withdraw into its armored shell. When it does so, it falls {@condition prone}. The blastoise's AC increases by 4 until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The blastoise can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Gigantamax
entries: When the blastoise is below half of its maximum hit points (175), it surges with limitless power, causing it to shift and grow to a staggering size. It gains the following benefits for 10 minutes:
- Its size grows to Gargantuan.
- Its Strength increases to 28, its Constitution to 30, and its Dexterity decreases to 5. The rest of its ability scores remain unchanged.
- Its resistances to nonmagical bludgeoning, slashing, and piercing damage become immunities.
- All of its attacks deal an additional 14 ({@damage 2d10}) damage of their original type and the radius of its area of effect attacks increase by 15 feet in all dimensions.
- It gains access to its cannonade attack (see actions).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The blastoise makes three attacks; one with its crunch and two with its claws. Alternatively, it can make two water gun attacks.

action.name: Crunch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, the blastoise can automatically hit it with its bite, and it can't use its bite against other targets.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Water Gun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@damage 4d8 + 8}) cold damage and the target is pushed up to 5 feet away from the blastoise.

action.name: Surf
entries: The blastoise conjures up a wave of water that crashes down on an area that it can see within 30 feet of it. The area can be up to 30 feet long, up to 15 feet wide, and up to 10 feet tall. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and being knocked {@condition prone} on a failed save, or half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone} on a successful one. The water then spreads out 15 feet across the ground in all directions, extinguishing unattended flames in the area. On a failed or successful save, the target is pushed up to 15 feet away from the direction the wave crashed down in.

action.name: Hydro Cannon {@recharge 5}
entries: The blastoise blasts a torrent of water in a line that is 100 feet long and 10 feet wide. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 3d10 + 8}) cold and bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone} on a failed save, or half as much damage and not be knocked {@condition prone} on a successful one. On a failed or successful save, the target is pushed up to 30 feet away from the blastoise.

action.name: Cannonade (Gigantamax; Recharge 7-8)
entries: The massive cannons on blastoise's back erupt into powerful gouts of water, spanning a line 120 feet long and 25 feet wide. Each target caught in the line must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 24 ({@dice 7d6 + 8}) cold and bludgeoning damage on a failed save and 14 ({@damage 4d6}) cold damage on the beginning of each of its turns for {@dice 1d4} additional rounds. On a successful save, a target takes half as much initial damage and no additional damage on each of its turns. On a failed or successful save, the target is pushed up to 50 feet away from the blastoise and is knocked {@condition prone}.

{@italic A lone blue, turtle-like creature, about the size of a large tortoise, hops and squeaks at the edge of a large, rippling lake.  From the bushes, a pair of cat-like eyes focus on the creature as a leopard prepares to pounce. As a felid scream erupts from the tree line, a powerful blast of water slams into the predator with such force to immediately send it sprawling backwards several feet. From the water, a massive snapping turtle rises from the surface, taking several hulking steps towards the small turtle. Two massive cannons of metallic carapace sprout from underneath its thick, spiked shell, dripping with water as thick clouds of water vapor puff from the barrels. }

Hulking, powerful reptiles with an affinity for water, blastoises are massive bipedal snapping turtles with two chitinous cannons, called “geysers,” extending from their shoulder blades, both of which are capable of producing powerful gouts of water that can easily punch through steel.

{@bold Water Lovers.} Out of all the amphibious creatures, none feel more at home in the water than a blastoise. Adapted to surviving in freshwater, saltwater, and anything in between, blastoises can be found wherever a body of water is nearby. Like most reptiles, they enjoy basking atop of rocks, soaking in the sun’s rays. Being the usual apex predator in an aquatic ecosystem, these massive turtles oftentimes bully even the most massive crocodiles into sharing their basking spots, and it isn’t uncommon to find a blastoise basking on the shore with a group of uncomfortable crocodiles.

{@bold Familial Reptiles.} Blastoises are extremely sociable creatures, preferring to create large family units, called nests. These nests are not confined to being of the same species, and most will consist of various creatures an individual blastoise has claimed or adopted over the course of its extensively long lifespan. For some odd reason, each creature in a nest seems to genuinely care and appreciate one another, no matter its individual species’ natural intelligence or lack thereof. As a result, nests can consist of natural predators and prey resting next to one another in a bundle of familial affection. While extremely friendly, blastoises are vastly protective over members of their nest and will not hesitate to blast a hole through any creature looking to prey on one of its “hatchlings,” be it a small insect or an ancient dragon.

{@bold Draconic Roots.} It has been speculated that blastoises share their roots with dragon turtles, given that both share a primordial intelligence and a similar overall appearance, although blastoises are often seen walking bipedally in contrast to the quadripedal locomotion of a dragon turtle. Additionally, their geysers may be a form of breath weapon, which would explain their seemingly magical ability to fire an infinite amount of water at such powerful pressures. Perhaps also their frightening ability to nearly triple in size when enraged can be attributed to draconic power. While oftentimes most interactions between two blastoises are friendly, involving a playful headbutt and an affectionate water squirt, occasionally two members will engage in an all-out war, usually when a member of one blastoise’s nest preys on a member of another. Bloodied and beaten, the two blastoises will surge with powerful, electrifying energy, expelling a massive blast of heated air before erupting to the size of mountains. The two blastoises will wrestle with one another, often wreaking havoc on the terrain around them before one or both is knocked out. Even after such an intense battle, the two blastoises will regard each other as good friends if they are ever to meet again.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The tortoise can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Massive Frame
entries: The tortoise can carry up to 20,000 pounds of weight atop its shell, but moves at half speed if the weight exceeds 10,000 pounds. Medium or smaller creatures can move underneath the tortoise while it's not {@condition prone}.
Any creature under the tortoise when it falls {@condition prone} is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}). Until the grapple ends, the creature is {@condition prone} and {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 3d12 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shell Defense {@recharge 4}
entries: The tortoise withdraws into its shell, falls {@condition prone}, and gains a +5 bonus to AC. While the tortoise is in its shell, its speed is 0 and can't increase. The tortoise can emerge from its shell as an action, whereupon it is no longer {@condition prone}.

Desolate badlands and soggy marshes are home to the ancient and massive horizonback tortoises. Nearly fifty feet from nose to tail, and with a habit of remaining stationary for long periods, a horizonback tortoise is easy to mistake for a low hill at a distance. But when these impressive creatures rise to begin their march, the sight inspires fear and awe in equal parts. An omnivore of incredible size, these scavengers prefer to feed on dead vegetation, but make use of whatever edible matter they come across.

trait.name: Spell Turning
entries: The chimera has advantage on a saving throw against any spell that targets only the chimera (not an area). If the chimera's saving throw is successful and the spell is of 4th level or lower, the spell has no effect on the chimera and instead targets the caster.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The chimera can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Bull Horns
entries: If the chimera moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a head attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chimera makes three attacks: one with its claws, one with its head, and one with its tail. When its breath weapon is available, it can use the breath in place of its head or its claws.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Head
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Venomous Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. A {@condition poisoned} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Venom Spray {@recharge 5}
entries: The chimera has a venomous creature's head that exhales a spray of poison in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a target takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

The term chimera applies to a wide variety of disparate monsters that combine the features of multiple beasts. While many artistic depictions represent chimeras as an amalgam of lion, ram, and dragon, these beasts appear with nearly endless variations.

The Akroans tell a tale of the first chimera's origin, wherein the god Keranos sought to test Nylea's favorite champion, Renata of Setessa, by creating a beast so deadly that even she would balk at trying to hunt it. When Renata slayed this lion-ram-dragon creation effortlessly, Keranos created another combination of deadlier beasts to challenge her. She slayed that beast, too. Despite countless attempts, Keranos was unable to create a beast that Renata couldn't best.

Chimeras typically roam the deep wilds of the world, constantly seeking a lair that would perfectly suit one of its heads, but then finding it unsatisfying to two-thirds of its being. As a result, a hungry chimera might appear out of a clear sky to pick off prey nearly anywhere. This threat grows even more significant in regions where magic runs rampant or where portals to the realm of Nyx exist, as unrestrained magical energy often causes more chimeras to appear in a region. As such chaotic magic is inherent to a chimera's being, these beasts often manage to shrug off spells cast against them.

entries.name: Customizing a Chimera
entries: The Theran chimera stat block presents one possible chimera configuration. You may customize these statistics to design your own unique chimera. To do so, simply roll once on one or all of the following tables. Results from the Body Composition table adjust the Theran chimera as described, while results on the Breath Weapons, Head Attacks, and Tail Attacks tables replace those respective actions in the stat block. Theran chimeras always have the Claws action. If the results of multiple tables conflict, chose your preferred result.

rows.name: Plains Creature
entries: The chimera's body is that of a large lowland creature, such as a bull or a bear, and it lacks wings and a flying speed. The chimera is especially resilient, gaining resistance to cold and fire damage.

rows.name: Coast Creature
entries: The chimera's body is that of a coastal or aquatic creature, such as a heron or a shark. The chimera gains a swimming speed equal to its walking speed and can breathe air and water.

rows.name: Mountain Creature
entries: The chimera's body is that of a mountain-dwelling creature, such as a ram or a dragon. The chimera doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

rows.name: Swamp Creature
entries: The chimera's body is that of a swamp creature or a cavern-dweller, such as a giant lizard or spider. The chimera gains a climbing speed equal to its walking speed and it can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

rows.name: Bull Horns
entries: If the chimera moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a head attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@dice 2d6}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

rows.name: Shark Bite
entries: The chimera has advantage on a head attack roll against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

rows.name: Unicorn Horn
entries: The chimera's head attack is magical and deals an extra 4 ({@dice 1d8}) radiant damage.

rows.name: Cockatrice Beak
entries: A creature hit by the chimera's head attack must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be restrained as it begins to turn to stone. The restrained creature must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is petrified for 24 hours.

rows.name: Lightning Breath (Recharge 5–6)
entries: The chimera exhales lightning in a 60-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ({@dice 8d8}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

rows.name: Tidal Wave Breath (Recharge 5–6)
entries: The chimera has an aquatic creature's head that exhales a torrent of acidic water in a 60-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On failed save, a creature takes 27 ({@dice 5d10}) acid damage and is knocked prone. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't knocked prone.

rows.name: Venom Spray (Recharge 5–6)
entries: The chimera has a venomous creature's head that exhales a spray of poison in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for 1 minute. While poisoned in this way, a target takes 35 ({@dice 10d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns. A target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

rows.name: Necrotic Breath (Recharge 5–6)
entries: The chimera exhales necrotic energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, or it takes 31 ({@dice 7d8}) necrotic damage and is unable to regain hit points until the end of its next turn.

rows.name: Venomous Tail
entries: The chimera's tail ends in a snake's head or a stinger, which deals piercing damage instead of bludgeoning damage. In addition, when the chimera hits a creature with its tail, the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 minute. A poisoned target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

rows.name: Perplexing Tail
entries: The chimera has an additional head where its tail should be. The chimera loses its tail attack and makes two head attacks when it takes the Multiattack action. Use the Head Attacks table to determine the nature of the new head.

rows.name: Shark Tail
entries: The chimera's tail is a large fin. When the chimera hits a creature with its tail, the creature is also pushed up to 10 feet away.

rows.name: Constricting Tail
entries: The chimera's tail can constrict prey. If the chimera hits a creature with its tail, the target is grappled (escape DC 15) if it is Large or smaller. Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, and the chimera can't use its tail on another target.

monster.name: The Sharptooth

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Sharptooth's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 18}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The Sharptooth has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Dread Reaper
entries: The Sharptooth delights in terrifying its prey and devouring them whilst they scream in horror. The Sharptooth scores a critical hit on any creature that is {@condition frightened} or {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The Sharptooth's long jump is up to 50 ft. and its high jump is up to 30 ft., with or without a running start.

trait.name: Savage Attacks
entries: When the Sharptooth scores a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, it can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The Sharptooth deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the Sharptooth moves at least 20 ft. straight toward a target and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the Sharptooth can make a bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Sharptooth fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Sharptooth makes three attacks: two with its bite and one with its stomp or tail. It can use a swallow in place of its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}41 ({@damage 5d12 + 9}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and The Sharptooth can't bite another target or use its prehistoric scream.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The Sharptooth makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, that creature takes the bite's damage and is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside Gishath, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of The Sharptooth's turns.

If The Sharptooth takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of it. If The Sharptooth dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d4 + 9}) slashing damage.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}31 ({@damage 4d10 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) bludgeoning damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw or be thrown up to 15 ft. away from The Sharptooth and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Prehistoric Scream (Recharge 5-6
entries: The Sharptooth emits a petrifying roar in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area that can hear the Sharptooth must make a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, a creature is {@condition frightened} and {@condition incapacitated} for 1 minute as the terror of extinction lays waste to their minds. On a success, a creature suffers no ill effects. An {@condition incapacitated} or {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending both effects on itself on a success.

legendaryHeader: The Sharptooth can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The Sharptooth regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Sharptooth makes one stomp or tail attack.

legendary.name: Rush
entries: The Sharptooth moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Tail Spin (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Sharptooth spins in a wide circle, swinging its tail at any creature within range. The Sharptooth makes a tail attack against each creature within 20 feet of it.

A manifestation of predatory malice in the form of nature's ultimate tyrant king, the Sharptooth dwarfs the largest of the behemoths, stomping, slashing, and tearing its way through the prehistoric jungles of Chult. It feeds on fear, preferring to fill its prey with the blind panic of complete extinctual annihilation whenever it roars, sending them into a thoughtless scramble, reducing them to nothing more than simple prey.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The utahraptor has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the utahraptor's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Agile
entries: The utahraptor can take the Dash or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Grasping Leap
entries: If the utahraptor moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and {@condition grappled}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the utahraptor can make one toe claw attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The utahraptor has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight or smell.

trait.name: Leaper
entries: The utahraptor's  long jump is up to 20 feet and its high jump is up to 10 feet, with or without a running start. Additionally. with a 10-foot running start, the utahraptor can long jump up to 30 feet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The utahraptor makes one bite attack and one claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Toe Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, one {@condition prone} target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

variant.name: Aberrant Raptors
entries: Deep within the underdark, utahraptors have evolved to be larger, faster, and more dangerous. They have also attained a form of bioluminescence that allows them to cast dancing lights at will.

At 7 feet long and over 1,000 pounds, the utahraptor is a terrible beast to behold. Often just referred to as "raptors," these bipedal carnivores are clever, silent, swift pack predators with jagged, sickle-shaped claws on their innermost toe.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 5d6}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until cured. While {@condition poisoned} this way, the target begins to degrade over the course of several hours until death or until the poison is cleansed. Every hour, the target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) poison damage and has its hit point maximum reduced by that amount. Additionally, the target gains a level of {@condition exhaustion} every hour. After two hours, the target is {@condition paralyzed}.

action.name: Spit {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) poison damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute.

The King Cobra is an extremely dangerous terrestrial serpent, primarily preying on small mammals, birds, reptiles, and even other cobras. The cobra is widely regarded as one of the most deadly and iconic snakes, recognized by its prominent hood. Unlike most snakes, the cobra is extremely aggressive, and is responsible for the deaths of thousands every year.

While most know the stories of cobras killing elephants by sinking their long fangs into the soft tips of the elephant's trunk, not many know of the tale of a mere cobra that defended its nest from a tyrannical dragon who accidentally stumbled upon the little creature's brood. Sinking its fangs into the soft portions of flesh underneath the dragon's deep red scales, the cobra injected its deadly venom, barely even phasing the dragon. Immediately struck by a wave of agony, the dragon struggled to fly to its mountainous lair to rest. Too proud and stubborn to seek assistance from creatures lower than itself, the dragon laid there, curled in a ball of blood and necrotic flesh before finally passing away.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The irukandji can breathe only underwater.

trait.name: Sting
entries: Any creature that the irukandji directly touches is subjected to its deadly neurotoxin. The stung target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw, taking 28 ({@damage 8d6}) poison damage and becoming {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour.  While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target becomes {@condition paralyzed} and {@condition incapacitated} after 20 minutes and they take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage every 5 minutes. At the end of the hour, the creature begins dying and makes death saving throws with disadvantage. If the target recovers before death, they are {@condition paralyzed} and {@condition incapacitated} for an additional {@dice 1d4} weeks.

The Irukandji is a miniscule jellyfish with a deadly secret. While many would simply glance at the tiny invertebrate and pay it no second thought, the creature is actually one of the most venomous creatures to roam the seas. The Irukandji jellyfish's stings are so severe that they often cause fatal brain hemorrhages and are the cause of over 600 deaths annually. Very little is truly known about the Irukandji, as it is an extremely small and fragile animal. However, they are known for causing an effect known as Irukandji syndrome in victims should they ever recover.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The funnel web spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the funnel web spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The funnel web spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}1 piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) poison damage and become {@condition poisoned}. A {@condition poisoned} creature develops the first symptoms of general weakness and lethargy within 1 hour as its bones start to rot from the inside. At the end of each long rest, the diseased creature must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or its Strength and Dexterity scores are each reduced by {@dice 1d4} and its walking speed is reduced by 5 feet. The reductions last until the target finishes a long rest after the poison is cured. If the poison reduces the creature's Strength or Dexterity to 0, the creature dies. A creature that succeeds on two saving throws against the poison recovers from it. Alternatively, the poison can be removed by the lesser restoration spell or similar magic.

The funnel web spider is by far the most venomous and potent spider in terms of general toxicity. Its venom can fell giants with just a single bite, and its fangs are long enough to pierce shoes, fingernails, and some armor. These arachnids reside underground in burrows when in their natural environment, but are most often encountered in marketplaces in homes. These spiders are extremely aggressive despite their small stature, actively chasing anything they perceive to be a threat to itself or its young.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1 + 3}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned}, the creature's mind is ravaged by a pulsing fever. The {@condition poisoned} creature has disadvantage on Intelligence checks and Intelligence saving throws, and the creature behaves as if under the effects of the confusion spell. In addition, over the course of several hours, the target is plagued by severe fatigue and cramps.

After one hour after envenomation, the target is overcome with shaking and vomiting as it is thrown into spontaneous, agonizing seizures and its organs begin to fail. The creature has disadvantage on all checks, saving throws, and attack rolls involving Strength and Dexterity.

After two hours, blood leaks from the target’s mouth, nose, and eyes uncontrollably. The creature has disadvantage on Constitution checks and Constitution saving throws. In addition, whenever the creature takes damage, it is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. It is also vulnerable to all physical damage as its skin begins to gradually slough off, revealing rotting, bleeding muscles.
After three hours, the target becomes {@condition paralyzed} as its nerves finally begin to cease function.
